THIRSIL.  THOMALIN.

A fisher-boy that never knew his peer</br>In daintie songs, the gentle Thomalin,</br>With folded arms, deep sighs, and heavy cheer</br>Where hundred Nymphs, and hundred Muses inne,</br>Sunk down by Chamus brinks; with him his deare,</br>Deare Thirsil lay; oft times would he begin</br>To cure his grief, and better way advise;</br>But still his words, when his sad friend he spies,</br>Forsook his silent tongue, to speak in watrie eyes.

Under a sprouting vine they carelesse lie,</br>Whose tender leaves bit with the Eastern blast,</br>But now were born, and now began to die;</br>The latter warned by the formers haste,</br>Thinly for fear salute the envious skie:</br>Thus as they sat, Thirsil embracing fast</br>His loved friend, feeling his panting heart</br>To give no rest to his increasing smart,</br>At length thus spake, while sighs words to his grief impart:

THIRSIL.</br>Thomalin, I see thy Thirsil thou neglect'st,</br>Some greater love holds down thy heart in fear;</br>Thy Thirsils love, and counsel thou reject'st;</br>Thy soul was wont to lodge within my eare:</br>But now that port no longer thou respect'st;</br>Yet hath it still been safely harbour'd there.</br>My eare is not acquainted with my tongue,</br>That either tongue, or eare should do thee wrong:</br>Why then should'st thou conceal thy hidden grief so long?

THOMALIN.</br>Thirsil, it is thy love that makes me hide</br>My smother'd grief from thy known faithfull eare:</br>May still my Thirsil safe, and merry 'bide;</br>Enough is me my hidden grief to bear:</br>For while thy breast in hav'n doth safely ride,</br>My greater half with thee rides safely there.
THIRSIL.</br>So thou art well; but still my better part,</br>My Thomalin, sinks loaden with his smart:</br>Thus thou my finger cur'st, and wound'st my bleeding heart.

How oft hath Thomalin to Thirsil vowed,</br>That as his heart, so he his love esteem'd!</br>Where are those oaths?  where is that heart bestowed,</br>Which hides it from that breast which deare it deem'd,</br>And to that heart room in his heart allowed?</br>That love was never love, but onely seem'd.</br>Tell me, my Thomalin, what envious thief</br>Thus robs thy joy:  tell me, my liefest lief:</br>Thou little lov'st me, friend, if more thou lov'st thy grief.

THOMALIN.</br>Thirsil, my joyous spring is blasted quite,</br>And winter storms prevent the summers ray:</br>All as this vine, whose green the Eastern spite</br>Hath di'd to black, his catching arms decay,</br>And letting go their hold for want of might,</br>Mar'l winter comes so soon, in first of May.
THIRSIL.</br>Yet see the leaves do freshly bud again:</br>Thou drooping still di'st in this heavie strain:</br>Nor can I see or end or cause of all thy pain.

THOMALIN.</br>No marvel, Thirsil, if thou dost not know</br>This grief, which in my heart lies deeply drown'd:</br>My heart it self, though well it feels his wo,</br>Knows not the wo it feels:  the worse my wound,</br>Which though I rankling finde, I cannot show.</br>Thousand fond passions in my breast abound;</br>Fear leagu'd to joy, hope and despair together,</br>Sighs bound to smiles; my heart though prone to either,</br>While both it would obey, 'twixt both obeyeth neither.

Oft blushing flames leap up into my face;</br>My guiltlesse cheek such purple flash admires:</br>Oft stealing tears slip from mine eyes apace,</br>As if they meant to quench those causelesse fires.</br>My good I hate; my hurt I glad embrace:</br>My heart though griev'd, his grief as joy desires:</br>I burn, yet know no fuel to my firing:</br>My wishes know no want, yet still desiring:</br>Hope knows not what to hope, yet still in hope aspiring.

THIRSIL.</br>Too true my fears:  alas, no wicked sprite,</br>No writhel'd witch, with spells or powerfull charms,</br>Or hellish herbs digg'd in as hellish night,</br>Gives to thy heart these oft and fierce alarms:</br>But Love, too hatefull Love, with pleasing spite,</br>And spitefull pleasure, thus hath bred thy harms,</br>And seeks thy mirth with pleasance to destroy.</br>'Tis Love, my Thomalin, my liefest boy;</br>'Tis Love robs me of thee, and thee of all thy joy.

THOMALIN.</br>Thirsil, I ken not what is hate, or Love,</br>Thee well I love, and thou lov'st me as well;</br>Yet joy, no torment, in this passion prove:</br>But often have I heard the fishers tell,</br>He's not inferiour to the mighty Jove;</br>Jove heaven rules; Love Jove, heav'n, earth, and hell:</br>Tell me, my friend, if thou dost better know:</br>Men say, he goes arm'd with his shafts, and bow;</br>Two darts, one swift as fire, as lead the other slow.

THIRSIL.</br>Ah heedlesse boy!  Love is not such a lad,</br>As he is fancy'd by the idle swain;</br>With bow and shafts, and purple feathers clad;</br>Such as Diana (with her buskin'd train</br>Of armed Nymphs along the forrests glade</br>With golden quivers) in Thessalian plain,</br>In level race outstrips the jumping Deer</br>With nimble feet; or with a mighty spear</br>Flings down a bristled bore, or els a squalid bear.

Love's sooner felt, then seen:  his substance thinne</br>Betwixt those snowy mounts in ambush lies:</br>Oft in the eyes he spreads his subtil ginne;</br>He therefore soonest winnes, that fastest flies.</br>Fly thence my deare, fly fast, my Thomalin:</br>Who him encounters once, for ever dies:</br>But if he lurk between the ruddy lips,</br>Unhappie soul that thence his Nectar sips,</br>While down into his heart the sugred poison slips!

Oft in a voice he creeps down through the eare:</br>Oft from a blushing cheek he lights his fire:</br>Oft shrouds his golden flame in likest hair:</br>Oft in a soft-smooth skin doth close retire:</br>Oft in a smile; oft in a silent tear:</br>And if all fail, yet Vertue's self he'l hire:</br>Himself's a dart, when nothing els can move.</br>Who then the captive soul can well reprove,</br>When Love, and Vertue's self become the darts of Love?

THOMALIN.</br>Sure, Love it is, which breeds this burning fever:</br>For late (yet all too soon) on Venus day,</br>I chanc't (Oh cursed chance, yet blessed ever!)</br>As carelesse on the silent shores I stray,</br>Five Nymphs to see (five fairer saw I never)</br>Upon the golden sand to dance and play:</br>The rest among, yet farre above the rest,</br>Sweet Melite, by whom my wounded breast,</br>Though rankling still in grief, yet joyes in his unrest.

There to their sportings while I pipe, and sing,</br>Out from her eyes I felt a firie beam,</br>And pleasing heat (such as in first of Spring</br>From Sol, inn'd in the Bull, do kindly stream)</br>To warm my heart, and with a gentle sting</br>Blow up desire:  yet little did I dream</br>Such bitter fruits from such sweet roots could grow,</br>Or from so gentle eye such spite could flow:</br>For who could fire expect hid in an hill of snow?

But when those lips (those melting lips) I prest,</br>I lost my heart, which sure she stole away:</br>For with a blush she soon her guilt confest,</br>And sighs (which sweetest breath did soft convey)</br>Betraid her theft:  from thence my flaming breast</br>Like thundring Aetna burns both night and day:</br>All day she present is, and in the night</br>My wakefull fancie paints her full to sight:</br>Absence her presence makes, darknes presents her light.

THIRSIL.</br>Thomalin, too well those bitter sweets I know,</br>Since fair Nicaea bred my pleasing smart:</br>But better times did better reason show,</br>And cur'd those burning wounds with heav'nly art.</br>Those storms of looser fire are laid full low;</br>And higher love safe anchours in my heart:</br>So now a quiet calm does safely reigne.</br>And if my friend think not my counsel vain;</br>Perhaps my art may cure, or much asswage thy pain.

THOMALIN.</br>Thirsil, although this witching grief doth please</br>My captive heart, and Love doth more detest</br>The cure, and curer, then the sweet disease;</br>Yet if my Thirsil doth the cure request,</br>This storm, which rocks my heart in slumbring ease,</br>Spite of it self, shall yeeld to thy behest.
THIRSIL.</br>Then heark how Tryphons self did salve my paining,</br>While in a rock I sat of love complaining;</br>My wounds with herbs, my grief with counsel sage restraining.
But tell me first; Why should thy partial minde</br>More Melite, then all the rest approve?

THOMALIN.</br>Thirsil, her beautie all the rest did blinde,</br>That she alone seem'd worthy of my love.</br>Delight upon her face, and sweetnesse shin'd:</br>Her eyes do spark as starres, as starres do move:</br>Like those twin-fires, which on our masts appear,</br>And promise calms.  Ah that those flames so clear</br>To me alone should raise such storms of hope and fear!

THIRSIL.</br>If that which to thy minde doth worthiest seem,</br>By thy wel-temper'd soul is most affected;</br>Canst thou a face worthy thy love esteem?</br>What in thy soul then love is more respected?</br>Those eyes which in their spheare thou, fond, dost deem</br>Like living starres, with some disease infected,</br>Are dull as leaden drosse:  those beauteous rayes,</br>So like a rose, when she her breast displayes,</br>Are like a rose indeed; as sweet, as soon decayes.

Art thou in love with words?  her words are winde,</br>As flit as is their matter, flittest aire.</br>Her beautie moves?  can colours move thy minde?</br>Colours in scorned weeds more sweet, and fair.</br>Some pleasing qualitie thy thoughts doth binde?</br>Love then thy self.  Perhaps her golden hair?</br>False metall, which to silver soon descends!</br>Is't pleasure then which so thy fancie bends?</br>Poore pleasure, that in pain begins, in sorrow ends!

What?  is't her company so much contents thee?</br>How would she present stirre up stormy weather,</br>When thus in absence present she torments thee?</br>Lov'st thou not one, but all these joyn'd together?</br>All's but a woman.  Is't her love that rents thee?</br>Light windes, light aire; her love more light then either.</br>If then due worth thy true affection moves,</br>Here is no worth.  Who some old hagge approves,</br>And scorns a beauteous spouse, he rather dotes, then loves.

Then let thy love mount from these baser things,</br>And to the highest love, and worth aspire:</br>Love's born of fire, fitted with mounting wings;</br>That at his highest he might winde him higher;</br>Base love, that to base earth so basely clings!</br>Look as the beams of that celestiall fire</br>Put out these earthly flames with purer ray;</br>So shall that love this baser heat allay,</br>And quench these coals of earth with his more heav'nly day.

Raise then thy prostrate love with towring thought;</br>And clog it not in chains, and prison here:</br>The God of fishers deare thy love hath bought:</br>Most deare he loves:  for shame, love thou as deare.</br>Next, love thou there, where best thy love is sought;</br>My self, or els some other fitting peer.</br>Ah might thy love with me for ever dwell!</br>Why should'st thou hate thy heav'n, and love thy hell?</br>She shall not more deserve, nor cannot love so well.

Thus Tryphon once did wean my fond affection;</br>Then fits a salve unto th' infected place,</br>(A salve of soveraigne and strange confection)</br>Nepenthe mixt with Rue, and Herb-de-grace:</br>So did he quickly heal this strong infection,</br>And to my self restor'd my self apace.</br>Yet did he not my love extinguish quite:</br>I love with sweeter love, and more delight:</br>But most I love that Love, which to my love ha's right.
THOMALIN.</br>Thrice happy thou that could'st!  my weaker minde</br>Can never learn to climbe so lofty flight.

THIRSIL.</br>If from this love thy will thou canst unbinde;</br>To will, is here to can:  will gives thee might:</br>'Tis done, if once thou wilt; 'tis done, I finde.</br>Now let us home:  for see, the creeping night</br>Steals from those further waves upon the land.</br>To morrow shall we feast; then hand in hand</br>Free will we sing, and dance along the golden sand.</br>
